text:
A very brief history of the post-1980 economy:
- The pay of the top 1% of earners has risen much faster than economic growth.
- The pay of the next 9% has risen with economic growth.
- The pay of the bottom 90% has trailed economic growth. 
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/24/opinion/income-inequality-upper-middle-class.html …

text:
I’d say:
1) Capitalism produces gains in living standards. Communism does not. 
2) Capitalism needs regulation to work best. The more unfettered version of the past four decades has served the U.S. middle class and working class poorly. It’s served the affluent very well.
author: DLeonhardt

text:
For what it’s worth, I’m not sold on Warren’s plan vs. a large increase in inheritance taxes. 

I am sold on the idea that the combination of a huge increase in top-end wealth/incomes and stagnation for the middle class is a serious problem for the US. I can’t tell if you agree.
author: DLeonhardt

text: I mean this: There is abundant evidence of stagnation for middle class and poor since the 1970s and especially since 2000. Weak income growth. Weak wealth growth or worse. Flat or falling life expectancy. Unhappiness about country. Etc. What do you think is the right response?

2. Let's start with the numbers. At Trump's current approval rating (about 40%), the GOP was trounced in the midterms. It lost the House popular vote by almost 9 percentage points. 

By comparison, no presidential race has been so lopsided since Reagan '84.
author: DLeonhardt

text: 1. Trump is in a considerably weaker position than many people realize. If he loses any support from Republicans, his presidency could easily enter the sort of vicious spiral that Bush's did in 2006-8 or, perhaps more relevantly, Nixon's did in 1973-4.
author: DLeonhardt

text: I’m sorry you didn’t like it, Robert. But I hope you’re well. Let’s have this debate in person sometime.
author: DLeonhardt

text:
Trump is weaker than is often understood:
- The Republicans lost the popular vote in the midterms by almost 9 percentage points, according to the final count.
- 40% is not a good approval rating
- He's more likely to get weaker than stronger in 2019. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/06/opinion/trump-2020-republicans-impeachment.html …
author: DLeonhardt

author: DLeonhardt

text: An impeachment in the next few months likely shores up Republican support for him in Congress. And that support is by no means guaranteed over the rest of 2019.
author: DLeonhardt

text:
Remember: Nixon was never impeached. But he was effectively removed. 

The goal today needs to be persuading Republicans that Trump has violated his constitutional oath and is unfit for office. Impeachment, right now, doesn’t do that. 

Investigate Trump. Focus on his corruption.
author: DLeonhardt

text:
President Trump is manifestly unfit for office and deserves to be removed, just as Nixon was. 

But Democrats should understand that a rushed impeachment would actually help Trump stay in office. A much better approach for now: Sustained investigations.
author: DLeonhardt

text:
5. Achieving this outcome won't be easy. And it should not involve a Democratic House quickly impeaching him -- which would actually be a favor to Trump. But achieving his removal from office is more plausible than many people seem to realize. 
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/05/opinion/sunday/trump-impeachment.html?action=click&module=Opinion&pgtype=Homepage …
author: DLeonhardt

text: 4. For the country’s sake, there is only one acceptable outcome, just as there was after Americans realized in 1974 that a criminal was occupying the Oval Office. The president must go.
author: DLeonhardt

text:
3. This list instead focuses on demonstrable ways that Trump has broken the law or violated his oath.

ONE: Trump has used the presidency for personal enrichment.
TWO: He has violated campaign finance law.
THREE: He has obstructed justice.
FOUR: He has subverted democracy.
author: DLeonhardt

text: 2. Trump's high crimes and misdemeanors can be separated into four categories. And this list is conservative. It does not include the possibility that his campaign coordinated strategy with Russia, nor his lazy approach to the job, like his refusal to read briefing books.
author: DLeonhardt

text: 1. The unrelenting chaos that President Trump creates can sometimes obscure the big picture. But the big picture is simple: The United States has never had a president as demonstrably unfit for the office.

text: You can also see that college is often even more financially valuable for non-low-income students. At the median, for example, college is worth $514k for non-low-income students vs. $443k for lower-income.

text: As you can see, college grads consistently earn hundreds of thousands of dollars more than high-school grads. The median college grad from a low-income family earns $443,000 more than the median high-school grad from a low-income family, for example.

text: I find both your argument and that of your critics to be serious.
author: DLeonhardt

text: Your last tweet is the heart of it. I’m don’t think I agree with “never work with Trump”. But I don’t find the view antithetical to serious policy argument. I find it part of such argument.
author: DLeonhardt

text: My point is that the “don’t work with Trump” is a *substantive* view. The fact that people express it doesn’t automatically mean they’re trying to undo norms or paint the other side as unserious. It’s a debate to have on the merits, rather than on the legitimacy of the view.
author: DLeonhardt

text: On other hand, it’s not as common as sometimes claimed by people who are being criticized. And it’s not the same as tough but substantive criticism that calls you wrong and your view damaging. Latter seems fine to me – including when I’m on the receiving end.
author: DLeonhardt

text: That people criticized you for doing so seems aok to me. But how did they do so? If you're claiming they tried to disallow you from participating in a debate, be specific about how. Called you corrupt? Something else? I agree that this is a real phenomenon.
author: DLeonhardt

text: Marc: I see your point. I also find that point more persuasive when it is specific. As Matt said, it's perfectly legitimate for people to criticize you for supporting any part of the Trump agenda, just as it is for you to support a specific Trump policy. Both are coherent views.
author: DLeonhardt

text: We mourn Janet Elder’s death, and we celebrate her life.
author: DLeonhardt

text:
This morning, Dean Baquet said: “There is no one who was more dedicated to The Times and great journalism and to the lives all of the people who produce it than Janet.”

She spent more than 30 years here. She helped make the modern New York Times.
author: DLeonhardt

text: Janet was also a fierce and necessary advocate for women at the NYT. She knew the obstacles they face, here and everywhere. She knew we had to do better.
author: DLeonhardt

text: One day, during the planning, I sheepishly went to her and said, “I think we need another editor.” She looked at our plan and said, “I think you need two more.” (And Janet was not usually in favor of spending more of the NYT’s money.)
author: DLeonhardt

text: ... more than any other NYT executive, she pushed for the creation of The Upshot, and she made sure we had the resources we needed to succeed.
author: DLeonhardt

text: Janet’s background was polling. She ran the NYT polling operation for years. She pushed it to do substantive polling, on race, class and other issues. She was rigorously skeptical of the newfangled ways that polls were and are being used. And yet ...
author: DLeonhardt

text: On hundreds of dispatches from around the globe over the years, it would have been accurate if the story had included a line at the end: Janet Elder contributed to this story.
author: DLeonhardt

text: Janet was most proud — deservedly — of her work making it possible for NYT journalists to do their work around the world. In various roles, including deputy executive editor, she did the things that protected them. She helped rescue them when they needed it.

text:
Yes, there are two problems on the corporate side: 
- It's a tax cut, not tax reform.
- It's too big of a tax cut.

Eliminating the second problem would help the politics of passing the bill but still leave the corporate part unimpressive from a policy standpoint.
author: DLeonhardt

text:
Another way to say "out of whack": The corporate side of the bill is mostly the easy stuff, like rate cuts. It is very light on the hard part of reform: Reducing wasteful tax breaks. 

Thus the huge overall cost of the corporate part of the bill.
